oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Slaves; Older people; Quilts; Log cabins; Slave quarters; Freedmen; Furniture; Beds; Chairs; Rocking chairs; Staffs (Sticks); Tables
Quilts; Hermitage (Hermitage, Tenn.); Slaves; Slaves -- Dwellings; Log cabins; Freedmen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alfred "Uncle Alfred" Jackson (circa 1812-1901), body servant of Andrew Jackson, sitting in his red cedar log cabin (built in 1841) at the Hermitage. A quilt is visible on the bed.

Alfred's mother Betty (1793-1870) was the Jackson's cook; his uncle George was Jackson's personal servant and later the family carriage driver. Alfred assisted with the horses, maintained the wagons and farm equipment, and after emancipation was a tenant farmer at the Hermitage. He became a handyman and tour guide after the Hermitage became a museum. He lived at the Hermitage until his death and is buried near Andrew and Rachel Jackson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unidentified young woman and infant with a large quilt

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Infants; Quilts
Quilts; Women; Infants; Mothers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified young woman holding an infant and standing in front of a large hanging quilt. The quilt is a Crazy quilt pattern.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Edna Mays Miracle Liming Family Photographs, ca. 1880s-1920s
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Japanese style of asymmetrical art was exhibited during the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876. The “Crazy” quilt pattern cropped up during the Victorian period as a way for women to include the Japanese design they had seen in their quilts. Most Crazy quilts were made with silk, satin, or velvet as opposed to cotton and were only used as display quilts. Crazy quilts can be identified by their uneven fabric blocks and the fine ornamental embroidery stitches on their tops. Popular decorative motifs on these quilts included fans, animals, and insects. Spiders and webs can often be seen on Crazy quilts as they were thought to bring good luck to the quiltmaker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Butterfly quilt detail
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilting; Quilts; Sewing
Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Close-up view of an area of a Butterfly quilt, showing details of the appliqued butterflies.

The word "quilt" is derived from the Latin word culcita, which means a stuffed sack, mattress, or cushion. A pieced butterfly is traditionally appliqued to a block, and the blocks are sewed together to form the quilt top. The Butterfly block pattern was a popular American design in the 1930s. The butterfly symbolized hope and new life during the Great Depression.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grandmother’s Flower Garden quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Grandmother's Flower Garden quilt hanging from a clothesline. The border of the quilt is lavender and the patterns are in five columns.

Dating to the 18th Century, the Grandmother's Flower Garden pattern is one of the most popular patters. It features hexagonal patches stiched together with the English paper piecing method. The English paper piecing method involves a hexagon template is cut out of paper or light cardboard for each hexagon patch and the patches are stiched together by hand.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large Butterfly quilt hanging from a clothesline. The quilt has alternating blocks of light and dark green set on point, so they appear as diamonds. A butterfly with brown-and-tan-checked wings is appliqued within each light green square.

The word "quilt" is derived from the Latin word culcita, which means a stuffed sack, mattress, or cushion. Butterfly quilts are made from butterfly blocks, smaller units that are later sewn together to form the quilt top. The Butterfly block pattern was a popular American design in the 1930s. The butterfly symbolized hope and new life during the Great Depression.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jewel Allen oral history excerpt about learning to piece quilts
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilting; Chairs; African Americans; Oral history
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio excerpt of Jewel Allen oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. He discusses how he used to bottom chairs during the winters while his wife pieced quilts. His wife taught him to piece quilts and she learned to bottom chairs. They fixed chairs in Carter, Mississippi; Collierville, Tennessee; and Memphis, Tennessee. He stopped working on chairs and took a job as a janitor at Allen White School after his wife died.

The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jewel Allen oral history excerpt discussing quilt patterns
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio excerpt of Jewel Allen oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. He discusses how his wife learned to quilt from her family and how he began quilting himself. People have offered to buy his quilts, but he did not feel they offered him enough for his work. He says he tries to make an honest living piecing quilts and bottoming chairs, but the living is meager and lonely.

The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts
Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Quilt made by Jewel Allen. The quilt is made of numerous, small, multi-colored squares, arranged in a Nine Patch pattern.

The first known Nine Patch quilts date from around 1800. The basic form of the quilt is very simple. Each block is made of nine equal squares, but there are dozens of variations. Many children learned to sew by making Nine Patch doll quilts.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dresden Plate quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dresden Plate quilt hanging from a clothesline. The quilt has a purple border and the pattern repeats across four columns.

The Dresden Plate quilt pattern was one of the most popular quilts made during the 1920s and 30s. It was also called Grandmother's Sunburst, Friendship Ring, Aster, Dahlia, and Sunflower. It is similar to the Fan patterns of the late 1800s. Some Dresden Plate blocks seem to be made of four fans sewn together. Dresden, Germany, was known for its fine porcelain plates, which seem to have inspired this design.

Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sunbonnet Sue quilt hanging from a clothesline. The border is red, and the pattern repeats across five columns.

Sunbonnet Sue is an applique pattern that probably dates to the 1870s, although the name "Sunbonnet Sue" itself dates to 1908. The pattern is also called Dutch Doll, Bonnie Bonnet, or Sunbonnet Babies.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three quilts hanging from a clothesline in front of a house.

Although quilting is known to have existed since ancient times, the art of quilting is uniquely associated with American women throughout United States history. Pioneer-era patchwork became a necessity when purchasing new fabric grew difficult or impossible. As families moved, the names of their quilt patterns sometimes changed along with their social circumstances, often producing many names for the same pattern.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Overall Bill, Star, and Dresden Plate quilts hanging from a clothesline. The focus is on the Star quilt and only small areas of the other two are visible.

Dresden Plate was a popular quilting pattern of the 1920s and 1930s. It is related to the 19th century Fan pattern. Overall Bill was a pattern related to and often used in alternating blocks with Sunbonnet Sue. Star quilts appeared in England and the eastern United States in the early 1800s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Handicraft; Quilting; Quilts; Sewing; Porches; Swings
Quilts; Quilting; Crossville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Nancey [sic] Page, a quiltmaker from Clifty, Tennessee, near Crossville, sitting on her front porch swing with a "Dutch Doll" or "Sunbonnet Sue" quilt across her lap.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The sunbonnet design in quilting originated in the 1870s, based on the motif of a broad-brimmed bonnet that obscures the face of a young girl. The pattern is frequently called "Sunbonnet Sue," after a popular 1908 song. The name was applied to the quilt pattern after the Great Depression. In the South, the name "Dutch Doll" persisted until after national publications helped standardize quilt pattern names.

Page, Nancy Scarbrough, 1874-1964. Quiltmakers - Tennessee. -- Quilting - Tennessee. -- Quilts - Tennessee - Cumberland County. -- Quilts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Nancy Page, a quiltmaker near Crossville, stands beside a quilt frame as she arranges her cotton batting.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nancy Page was the widow of Robert Lee Page, who died on March 26, 1918. They married in White County on August 1, 1892, and had four children: William Alexander, Hobert, Veda, and Helen Roberta.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio excerpt of Carlock Stookesbury oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. He discusses his wife's wintertime quilting. He mentions that she hangs the quilts from the ceiling over the bed. He also talks about tacking comforters and various types of needlework. He explains the difference between tacking comforters and quilts.

Quilts; Invitation cards; Art -- Exhibitions
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Invitation to the Quilts of Tennessee Exhibit at the Hunter Museum of Art features a yellow quilt on the cover and accompanying text.

The Hunter Museum of American Art focuses on American art from the Colonial period to the present day. It not only features drawings, paintings, and sculpture by many well known artists, but also includes furniture and contemporary studio glass.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting; Folk art; Quiltmakers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: List of the quilt pattern names on Walden's Ridge. The top of the document states, "Names of quilts on Walden's Ridge copied from Mrs. Rawk's patterns." The following quilt patterns are named: Broken Circle, Star of Bethlehem, Old Maid's Puzzle, Twin Sisters, Catch Me If You Can, Rolling Stone, Bird In The Air, The Beggar's Patch, The Wild Goose, Double T, The Arkansas Traveler, and The Hand Of Friendship.
Walden's Ridge is part of Signal Mountain, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Beds; Chairs; Tables
Quilts; Quilting; Folk art; Beds; Chairs; Tables
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bedroom in the home of Susie Gentry in Franklin, Tennessee. A canopy bed can be seen. A Swamp Lily patterned quilt is on the bed. There is a chair visible at the foot of the bed and a small night table at its head.

Susie Gentry (1860-1944) was a genealogist, artist, composer, historian, and regent of the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Williamson County. She was the only child of Watson Meredith and Martha A. (Jones) Gentry. She is buried at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Franklin, Tennessee.

Susie Gentry (1860-1944) was a genealogist, artist, composer, historian, and regent of the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Williamson County. She was the only child of Watson Meredith and Martha A. (Jones) Gentry. She is buried at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Franklin, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bethlehem Star quilt made by Mrs. W. M. Gentry
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting; Folk Art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bethlehem Star quilt made by Mrs. W. M. Gentry. The quilt has an eight pointed star in the center with Crazy quilt style blocks surrounding it.

Martha A. (Jones) Gentry of Franklin, Tennessee, was the wife of Watson Meredith Gentry. Her daughter was Susie Gentry (1860-1944). Susie Gentry was a genealogist, artist, composer, historian, and regent of the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Williamson County. Eight pointed star quilts appeared in England and the eastern United States in the early 1800s. The tiny, colorful diamonds can resemble the patterns of a kaleidoscope. Also known as Star of the East, Star of Bethlehem, and Lone Star, this pattern is popular with Native American quilters. The Japanese style of asymmetrical art was exhibited during the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876. The "Crazy" quilt pattern cropped up during the Victorian period as a way for women to include the Japanese design they had seen in their quilts. Most Crazy quilts were made with silk, satin, or velvet as opposed to cotton and were only used as display quilts. Crazy quilts can be identified by their uneven fabric blocks and the fine ornamental embroidery stitches on their tops. Popular decorative motifs on these quilts included fans, animals, and insects. Spiders and webs can often be seen on Crazy quilts as they were thought to bring good luck to the quiltmaker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. Watson M. Gentry
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Martha A. Jones (Mrs. Watson Meredith) Gentry wearing a lace-collared dress and three strands of pearls.

Martha A. (Jones) Gentry of Franklin, Tennessee, was the wife of Watson Meredith Gentry. Her daughter was Susie Gentry (1860-1944). Susie Gentry was a genealogist, artist, composer, historian, and regent of the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Williamson County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Dresses
Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Miss Susie Gentry posing in front of a matte painting of stairs. She wears a bustle dress, has a feathered hair accessory, and holds a fan possibly made of lace. One of her shoes is visible below her dress.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: White, W. W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Susie Gentry (1860-1944) was a genealogist, artist, composer, historian, and regent of the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Williamson County. She was the only child of Watson Meredith and Martha A. (Jones) Gentry. She is buried at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Franklin, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: West Tennessee District Fair Western State Hospital booth

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Furniture; Rugs; Exhibit booths
Quilts; Quilting; Fairs; Exhibitions; Occupational therapy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Western State Hospital Occupational Therapy Unit's booth at the West Tennessee District Fair. The booth shows a number of craft items including applique quilts, furniture, wall hangings, lamps, baskets, and brooms.

Western State Mental Hospital was located in Bolivar, Tennessee. Occupational Therapy is the process of using occupation-based activities in therapy sessions for individuals with physical and/or mental disabilties.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nan Ross standing in front of a Crazy quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Families; Quilts; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nan Ross standing in front of a Crazy quilt. The quilt was made between February and December 1898 by Nan, Mattie, and Sue Ross and their mother Elizabeth Charles Ross. It has the marriage date of Tom and Elizabeth Ross as well as the initials of all twelve of their children.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: TSLA Staff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Japanese style of asymmetrical art was exhibited during the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876. The "Crazy" quilt pattern cropped up during the Victorian period as a way for women to include the Japanese design they had seen in their quilts. Most Crazy quilts were made with silk, satin, or velvet as opposed to cotton and were only used as display quilts. Crazy quilts can be identified by their uneven fabric blocks and the fine ornamental embroidery stitches on their tops. Popular decorative motifs on these quilts included fans, animals, and insects. Spiders and webs can often be seen on Crazy quilts as they were thought to bring good luck to the quiltmaker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rupper family posing in front of two quilts
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Families; Suits (Clothing)
Quilts; Quilting; Temperance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Family portrait of the Rupper family, from Hebbertsburg, Tennessee, posed in front of two hanging quilts. The image features eight family members. Two quilts hang behind them. One quilt features a Double T pattern, and the other has a series of large squares made of small triangles.

The quilt on the left features a Double T or "Temperance T" pattern frequently used to signify the belief in being a "teetotaler" within the temperance movement. The Women's Christian Temperance Movement was founded in 1874 and had over 350,000 members by 1907.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilting bees; Yards; Women; Houses; Children
Quilts, Quilting, Quiltmakers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Quilting party in the front yard of the Shell house, Cherokee Community. Edna Richardson is seated in the front and Marie Taylor Harvey is standing in the extreme back. Various unidentified women and children are also shown.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: TSLA Staff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The quilting bee became a tradition probably during the 19th Century. Many bees were simply an occasion wherein women assisted one another in finishing quilts. They eventually became an opportunity for women to gather in a social environment. The bee itself often featured a large wooden frame around which many women would work on the same quilt.

Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Quilting bee featuring seven women sitting around a quilting frame. One of the women on the left has a child in her lap. Another woman stands next to the frame, and a group of six children can be seen standing in the background.

The quilting bee became a tradition probably during the 19th Century. Many bees were simply an occasion wherein women assisted one another in finishing quilts. They eventually became an opportunity for women to gather in a social environment. The bee itself often featured a large wooden frame around which many women would work on the same quilt.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Families; Infants; Quilts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hedgecoths and the Hambys of Hebbertsburg, Tennessee, posed in front of a Crazy quilt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: TSLA Staff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The two infants pictured were born about nine days apart and later married each other. The Japanese style of asymmetrical art was exhibited during the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876. The “Crazy” quilt pattern cropped up during the Victorian period as a way for women to include the Japanese design they had seen in their quilts. Most Crazy quilts were made with silk, satin, or velvet as opposed to cotton and were only used as display quilts. Crazy quilts can be identified by their uneven fabric blocks and the fine ornamental embroidery stitches on their tops. Popular decorative motifs on these quilts included fans, animals, and insects. Spiders and webs can often be seen on Crazy quilts as they were thought to bring good luck to the quiltmaker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woman helping a man working on a Nine Patch quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Quilts; Quilting; Men
Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified woman assisting a man as he makes a Nine Patch quilt. A pair of needle-nose pliers and a pair of scissors are on the table in front of the man.

Nine Patch quilts date back to the 19th Century. The quilt consists of nine equal squares but can be arranged in numerous ways. It is a popular beginner's pattern and is found in many children's and doll quilts.

Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four unidentified women working on a quilt in Hoyt Wakefield's home. The women are at one corner of the frame with a cabinet standing in the corner of the room behind them. A closed plank door can be seen in the background, and an open door leading to a room with a bed is visible on the right.

The quilting bee became a tradition probably during the 19th Century. Many bees were simply an occasion wherein women assisted one another in finishing quilts. They eventually became an opportunity for women to gather in a social environment. The bee itself often featured a large wooden frame around which many women would work on the same quilt.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence between Mrs. John Trotwood Moore and Miss Susie Gentry
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two letters of correspondence between Mrs. John Trotwood Moore and her cousin, Susie Gentry. The first item of correspondence is from Susie Gentry to Mary Daniel Moore, written from Franklin, Tennessee, on May 28, 1934. In her correspondence, Gentry discusses the Natchez Trace Road, the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Colonel Thomas Hart Benton Chapter of the United States Daughters of the War of 1812, and an inkblot she has made to look like a boy. The second piece of correspondence is a response from Mrs. Moore, dated June 1, 1934. Mrs. Moore states that she didn't know what an artist Miss Gentry was until she saw her lovely quilt and the ink spot on her letter.

Mary Daniel Moore and Susie Gentry were cousins. Moore served as State Librarian and Archivist from 1929-1949. Gentry organized the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Colonel Thomas Hart Benton Chapter of Daughters of the War of 1812, and the Watauga Cumberland Settlers Association. She also served as an officer in the Colonial Dames.
